[[Prisoner of War Medal]] }} '''Jeremiah Andrew Denton Jr.''' (July 15, 1924 – March 28, 2014) was a [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] representing [[Alabama]] from 1981 to 1987, a [[United States Navy]] [[Rear Admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] and [[Naval Aviator]] [[Prisoner of War|taken captive]] during the [[Vietnam War]]. Denton was widely known for enduring almost eight years of grueling conditions as an American [[prisoner of war]] (POW) in [[Vietnam|North Vietnam]] after the [[Grumman A-6 Intruder|A-6 Intruder]] he was piloting was shot down in 1965. He was the first of all American POWs held captive and released by Hanoi to step off an American plane during [[Operation Homecoming]] in February 1973. As one of the earliest and highest-ranking officers to be taken prisoner in North Vietnam, Denton was forced by his captors to participate in a 1966 televised propaganda interview which was broadcast in the United States. While answering questions and feigning trouble with the blinding television lights, Denton blinked his eyes in [[Morse code]], spelling the word "TORTURE"—and confirming for the first time to U.S. [[Office of Naval Intelligence|Naval Intelligence]] that American POWs were being [[torture]]d. In 1976, Denton wrote ''[[When Hell Was in Session]]'' about his experience in captivity, which was made into the 1979 film with [[Hal Holbrook]]. Denton was also the subject of the 2015 documentary ''Jeremiah'' produced by [[Alabama Public Television]]. ==Biography== Denton was born July 15, 1924, in [[Mobile, Alabama]], the oldest of three brothers, and the son of Jeremiah, Sr. and Irene (Steele) Denton."United States Census, 1940," index and images, FamilySearch (https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/V1PV-TV3 : accessed 28 Mar 2014), Irene S Denton, Ward 8, Mobile, Mobile City, Mobile, Alabama, United States; citing enumeration district (ED) 49-98A, sheet 8B, family 161, NARA digital publication of T627, roll 65."Alabama, County Marriages, 1809-1950," index and images, FamilySearch ([https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/VRV7-5HT] : accessed 28 Mar 2014), Jeremiah Andrew Denton and Irene Claudia Steele, 22 Aug 1922; citing Mobile County; FHL microfilm 1550499. He attended [[McGill-Toolen Catholic High School]] and [[Spring Hill College]] in [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]], Alabama. ===Military career=== In June 1943, he entered the [[United States Naval Academy]] in [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], [[Maryland]], and graduated three years later in the accelerated Class of 1947 on June 5, 1946, with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree. His 34-year naval career included service on a variety of ships and on aircraft, including airships (blimps). His principal field of endeavor was naval operations. He also served as a test pilot, flight instructor, and commanding officer of an attack squadron flying the [[A-6 Intruder]]. In 1957, he was credited with revolutionizing naval strategy and tactics for nuclear war as architect of the "Haystack Concept." This strategy called for concealing aircraft carriers from radar by intermingling with commercial shipping and avoiding formations suggestive of a naval fleet. The strategy was simulated in maneuvers and demonstrated effectiveness, allowing two aircraft carrier fleets thirty-five simulated atomic launches before aggressor aircraft and submarines could repel them.{{cite journal|last=Angevine |first=Robert |title=Hiding in Plain Sight: The US Navy and Dispersed Operations Under EMCON 1956-1972 |journal=Naval War College Review |date=Spring 2011 |volume=64 |issue=2 |pages=80–82 |url=http://www.usnwc.edu/getattachment/bfd7502d-682c-444d-946c-63245227ae68/Hiding-in-Plain-Sight--The-U-S--Navy-and-Dispersed |accessdate=9 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118061108/http://www.usnwc.edu/getattachment/bfd7502d-682c-444d-946c-63245227ae68/Hiding-in-Plain-Sight--The-U-S--Navy-and-Dispersed |archivedate=18 November 2011 |df= }} He went on to serve on the staff of the Commander, [[U.S. Sixth Fleet]] at the rank of Commander (O-5) as Fleet Air Defense Officer. Denton graduated from the [[Armed Forces Staff College]] and the [[Naval War College]], where his thesis on international affairs received top honors by earning the prestigious President's Award. In 1964, he received the degree of [[Master of Arts]] in [[International Affairs]] from [[George Washington University]]'s School of Public and International Affairs in [[Washington, D.C.]] ====Vietnam War==== {{main|U.S. Prisoners of War during the Vietnam War}} Denton served as a [[United States Naval Aviator]] during the [[Vietnam War]]. In February 1965, he became the [[Prospective Commanding Officer]] of [[Second VA-75 (U.S. Navy)|Attack Squadron Seventy-Five]] serving aboard aircraft carrier [[USS Independence (CV-62)|USS ''Independence'' (CVA-62)]]. On July 18, 1965, [[Commander|CDR]] Denton was piloting his [[Grumman A-6 Intruder|A-6A Intruder jet]] ([[Bureau Number|BUNO]] 151577) while leading a twenty-eight aircraft bombing mission over North Vietnam off the ''Independence'' which was stationed in the [[South China Sea]]. He and [[Lieutenant Junior Grade|LTJG]] Bill Tschudy, his [[Bombardier (aircrew)|bombardier/navigator]], were forced to eject from their plane after it was hit by enemy antiaircraft fire and went down out of control over the village of Thanh Hoa near Hanoi in North Vietnam. Both men were quickly captured and taken prisoner. Denton and Tschudy were held as prisoners of war for almost eight years, four of which were spent in solitary confinement. Denton was notable for his leadership during the [[Hanoi March]] in July 1966, when he and over 50 American prisoners were paraded through the streets of Hanoi and beaten by North Vietnamese civilians.Stuart I. Rochester and Frederick Kiley, ''Honor Bound: American Prisoners of War in Southeast Asia 1961-1973'' (Annapolis: Naval Institute Press, 1998) Denton is best known from this period of his life for the 1966 televised press conference in which he was forced to participate as an American POW by his North Vietnamese captors. He used the opportunity to send a distress message confirming for the first time to the U.S. [[Office of Naval Intelligence]] and Americans that American POWs were being tortured in North Vietnam. He repeatedly blinked his eyes in [[Morse code]] during the interview, spelling out "T-O-R-T-U-R-E". He was also questioned about his support for the U.S. war effort in [[Vietnam]], to which he replied: "I don't know what is happening, but whatever the position of my government is, I support it fully. Whatever the position of my government, I believe in it, yes sir. I am a member of that government, and it is my job to support it, and I will as long as I live."{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/exhibits/eyewitness/flash.php |title=Eyewitness |publisher=Archives.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-11-19}} While a prisoner, he was promoted to the rank of [[Captain (United States)|captain]]. Denton was later awarded the [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]] and other decorations for heroism while a prisoner of war. [[Image:J Denton speech.JPG|thumb|right|Navy Captain Jeremiah Denton at [[Clark Air Base]], [[Philippines]], shortly after his release as a POW in Hanoi, in February 1973.]] Denton was put in the "[[Hanoi Hilton]]" and the "Zoo" prison and prison camp and "Little Vegas" and "Alcatraz" prisons. In "Alcatraz", he became part of a group of American POWs known as the "[[Alcatraz Gang]]". The group consisted of [[George Thomas Coker|George Coker]], Harry Jenkins, [[Sam Johnson]], George McKnight, James Mulligan, Howard Rutledge, Robert Shumaker, [[James Stockdale]] (he graduated with Denton from the Naval Academy), Ronald Storz, and Nels Tanner. They were put in "Alcatraz" and [[solitary confinement]] to separate them from other POWs because their strong resistance led other POWs in resisting their captors. "Alcatraz" was a special facility in a courtyard behind the North Vietnamese Ministry of National Defense, located about one mile away from Hoa Lo Prison. Each of the American POWs spent day and night in windowless {{convert|3|x|9|ft|m|adj=on}} cells mostly in [[Legcuffs|legcuffs]].Adams, Lorraine. [http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920331&slug=1483968 "Perot's Interim Partner Spent 7½ Years As Pow"], ''[[Dallas Morning News]]'', March 11, 1992. Accessed July 2, 2008. "He was one of the ''Alcatraz Gang'' – a group of eleven prisoners of war who were separated because they were leaders of the prisoners' resistance."[[Stuart Rochester|Rochester, Stuart]]; and Kiley, Frederick. [https://books.google.com/books?id=IGemFZmcn_AC&pg=PA326 "Honor Bound: American Prisoners of War in Southeast Asia, 1961–1973"], 2007, [[United States Naval Institute|Naval Institute Press]], {{ISBN|1-59114-738-7}}, via [[Google Books]], p. 326. Accessed July 8, 2008.[[James Stockdale|Stockdale, James B.]] "George Coker for Beach Schools", letter to ''[[The Virginian-Pilot]]'', March 26, 1996.{{cite news |last = Johnston |first = Laurie |title = Notes on People, Mao Meets Mobutu in China |work= [[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/12/18/archives/mao-meets-mobut-in-china-notes-on-people.html | date=December 18, 1974 | accessdate=May 3, 2010}} Dec 18, 1974{{cite news|url=http://hamptonroads.com/2008/11/our-pows-locked-6-years-he-unlocked-spirit-inside|title=Our POW's: Locked up for 6 years, he unlocked a spirit inside|last=Kimberlin|first=Joanne|date=2008-11-11|work=The Virginian Pilot|publisher=Landmark Communications|pages=12–13|accessdate=2008-11-11}} On February 12, 1973, both Denton and Tschudy were released in Hanoi by the North Vietnamese along with numerous other American POWs during [[Operation Homecoming]]. Stepping off the jet back home in uniform, Denton said: "We are honored to have had the opportunity to serve our country under difficult circumstances. We are profoundly grateful to our [[Commander-in-Chief]] and to our nation for this day. God bless America." The speech has a prominent place in the 1987 documentary, ''[[Dear America: Letters Home from Vietnam]]''. Denton was briefly hospitalized at the [[Naval Medical Center Portsmouth|Naval Hospital Portsmouth, Virginia]], and then was assigned to the Commander, Naval Air Forces, U.S. Atlantic Fleet, from February to December 1973. In January 1974, Denton became the commandant of the [[Armed Forces Staff College]] in Norfolk (now known as the [[Joint Forces Staff College]]),{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9t5LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_YoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7313%2C2056338 |work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |agency=Associated Press |title=Denton unhappy, may leave Navy |date=May 15, 1975 |page=5}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-N5LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_YoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7116%2C2505843|work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |agency=Associated Press |last=Riley |first=Dave |title=Admiral wants to improve morality |date=May 17, 1975 |page=4}} to June 1977.{{cite web|last=Jones |first=Matthew |url=http://hamptonroads.com/2008/08/exvietnam-war-pow-man-committed-cooperation |title=Ex-Vietnam War POW a man committed to cooperation | HamptonRoads.com | PilotOnline.com |publisher=HamptonRoads.com |date=2008-08-13 |accessdate=2012-11-19}} His final assignment was as special assistant to the Chief of Naval Education and Training at [[Naval Air Station Pensacola]], [[Florida]], from June 1977 until his retirement from the Navy on November 1, 1977 with the rank of [[Rear admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]]. He wrote his book in 1976, ''[[When Hell was in Session]]'', detailing his detention as an American [[POW]] in North Vietnam,{{ISBN|978-1935071150}} which was made into a television movie of the same title in 1979, starring [[Hal Holbrook]] as Denton. ====After retirement==== Denton accepted a position with the [[Christian Broadcasting Network]] (CBN) as a consultant to CBN founder and friend, [[Pat Robertson]], from 1978 to 1980. During his time with CBN, both Denton and Robertson repeatedly expressed support for the [[Contras|Contra]] forces in [[Nicaragua]]. In 1981, he founded and chaired the National Forum Foundation. Through his National Forum Foundation, Denton arranged shipments of donated goods to countries in need of aid.{{cite news|title=Ex-senator and Vietnam POW who blinked "torture" in Morse code dies|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/jeremiah-denton-ex-senator-and-vietnam-pow-who-blinked-torture-in-morse-code-dies-at-89/|accessdate=6 October 2014|publisher=CBS News|date=28 March 2014}} ==Political career== [[File:President Ronald Reagan, in the Oval Office, shaking hands with Republican Senator Jeremiah Denton of Alabama.jpg|thumb|right|Denton with [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1986]] In 1980, Denton ran as a [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] for a U.S. Senate seat from his home state of Alabama. In the primary election, he easily defeated former U.S. Congressman [[Armistead Selden]], who was the candidate of choice of the Republican establishment in the state. He then achieved a surprise victory with 50.15 percent of the vote in November over [[U.S. Democratic Party|Democratic]] candidate [[Jim Folsom Jr.]], who himself had defeated the incumbent, [[Donald Stewart (Alabama)|Donald W. Stewart]], in the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] primary election. In doing so, Denton became the first {{Clarify|date=December 2017}} retired Navy admiral elected to the United States Senate. He was the second {{Clarify|date=December 2017}} retired Navy admiral to serve in the U.S. Senate as Admiral [[Thomas C. Hart]], U.S. Navy (ret.) of [[Connecticut]] served from November 15, 1945 to November 5, 1946. He was the first Republican to be popularly elected in Alabama since the direct election of U.S. Senators began in 1913, the first Republican senator since [[Reconstruction era in the United States|Reconstruction]] to represent Alabama in the U.S. Senate, and the first Catholic to be elected to statewide office in Alabama. Compiling a conservative voting record in the U.S. Senate, Denton was featured in a 1981 article in ''[[Time Magazine]]'' called "An Admiral from Alabama".[http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,922541,00.html An Admiral from Alabama] Time. 8 June 1981. Retrieved 11 September 2016. As a Senator, Denton was most outspoken on issues related to the preservation of the nuclear family, a goal that he sought to pursue through a $30 million bill to push chastity among teenagers. Denton also chaired a subcommittee on internal security and terrorism, which focused on communist and Soviet threats. By the mid-1980s, he told Time magazine at the outset of the decade, "We will have less national security than we had proportionately when George Washington’s troops were walking around barefoot at Valley Forge." Adm. Denton was one of a large group of Republican Senators who were swept into office along with the election of [[Ronald Reagan]] as the President in 1980. Then in 1986, because of perceived failures in the Reagan Administration (including the [[Iran-Contra Affair]]), all but one of these Republicans (see: [[United States Senate elections, 1986]]) were voted out of office and replaced by Democrats. The only exception was with Sen. Ron East of North Carolina, who had died in office in early 1986. His temporary replacement was not elected in November, either. In 1986, Denton [[United States Senate election in Alabama, 1986|narrowly lost his bid for reelection]] to the U.S. Senate, receiving 49.72 percent of the vote against U.S. Congressman [[Richard Shelby]], a conservative Democrat. ==Personal life== In 2007, Denton's first wife and the mother of his seven children, the former Katherine Jane Maury, died after sixty-one years of marriage. He subsequently married Mary Belle Bordone in 2010. Denton died of complications from a heart ailment at a hospice in Virginia Beach on March 28, 2014, at age 89.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/jeremiah-a-denton-jr-vietnam-pow-and-us-senator-dies/2014/03/28/1a15343e-b500-11e3-b899-20667de76985_story.html|title=Jeremiah A. Denton Jr., Vietnam POW and U.S. senator, dies|work=The Washington Post|date=March 28, 2014|accessdate=March 28, 2014}} He is buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]] with his wife Jane.{{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jmdenton.htm|title=Jane Maury Denton|accessdate=July 28, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/h-2969|title=Jeremiah Denton Jr|work=Encyclopedia of Alabama|accessdate=July 28, 2018}} ==Military awards== Denton's awards and decorations include:{{cite web|url=http://www.veterantributes.org/TributeDetail.php?recordID=278 |title=Veteran Tributes |publisher=Veteran Tributes |date= |accessdate=2017-11-15}}

===Navy Cross citation=== [[File:Navy_Cross.png|50px|left]] :Denton Jr., Jeremiah Andrew :Rear Admiral (then Commodore), U.S Navy :Prisoner of War in North Vietnam :Date of Action: February 1966 – May 1966 :Citation: The President of the United States of America takes pleasure in presenting the Navy Cross to Rear Admiral [then Commander] Jeremiah Andrew Denton Jr. (NSN: 0-485087), United States Navy, for extraordinary heroism while serving as a [[U.S. prisoners of war during the Vietnam War|Prisoner of War in North Vietnam]] from February 1966 to May 1966. Under constant pressure from North Vietnamese interrogators and guards, Rear Admiral Denton experienced harassment, intimidation and ruthless treatment in their attempt to gain military information and cooperative participation for propaganda purposes. During this prolonged period of physical and mental agony, he heroically resisted cruelties and continued to promulgate resistance policy and detailed instructions. Forced to attend a press conference with a Japanese correspondent, he blinked out a distress message in Morse Code at the television camera and was understood by United States Naval Intelligence. When this courageous act was reported to the North Vietnamese, he was again subjected to severe brutalities. Displaying extraordinary skill, fearless dedication to duty, and resourcefulness, he reflected great credit upon himself, and upheld the highest traditions of the Naval Service and the United States Armed Forces.{{cite web|author=Jeremiah Andrew Denton , Jr. |url=http://valor.militarytimes.com/recipient.php?recipientid=4410 |title=Valor awards for Jeremiah Andrew Denton , Jr [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Tim Rice * Andrew Lloyd Webber * [[Marc Platt (producer)|Marc Platt]] * [[Craig Zadan]] * [[Neil Meron]] * John Legend * Mike Jackson * Ty Stiklorius * Alex Rudzinski }} | producer = | cinematography = | editor = | camera = | runtime = 140 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * {{nowrap|[[Sony Pictures Television]]}} * Storyline Entertainment * Marc Platt Productions * [[Universal Television]] }} | distributor = | network = [[NBC]] | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[HDTV]]) | audio_format = | first_aired = {{startdate|2018|04|01}} | preceded_by = ''[[Hairspray Live!]]'' | followed_by = ''[[Hair Live!]]'' | website = http://www.nbc.com/jesus-christ-superstar | website_title = Official website }} '''''Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert''''' is an American musical television special that was broadcast live on [[NBC]] on April 1, 2018 ([[Easter]] Sunday). Executive produced by [[Craig Zadan]], [[Neil Meron]], [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]], [[Tim Rice]], and [[Marc Platt (producer)|Marc Platt]], it was a staged concert performance of the 1970 [[rock opera]] ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]''. ==Description and plot== {{main|Jesus Christ Superstar#Plot}} The musical is almost entirely sung-through, with a minimal to no amount of spoken dialogue. The plot is loosely based on the [[Canonical Gospel]]s' accounts of the last week of the life of Jesus Christ, beginning with the preparation for the arrival of Jesus and his disciples in Jerusalem and ending with the crucifixion. The apostle Judas Iscariot is worried that Jesus has become too swept up in the adoration of his followers, rather than focusing on his teachings about taking care of the poor, and that his following has grown too large and outspoken, which could soon provoke the wrath of the Roman empire ("Heaven on Their Minds"). Judas also object to Jesus spending his time with Mary Magdalene ("What's the Buzz / Strange Thing Mystifying"), who advises Jesus to relax ("Everything's All Right"). Judas's fears prove justified as priests Caiaphas, Annas and more gather and agree that Jesus and his movement must be crushed ("This Jesus Must Die"). Jesus enters Jerusalem filled with exaltation ("Hosanna") until he discovers that his temple has become overrun with unscrupulous merchants and money lenders. Overwhelmed by a throng of people needing his assistance, he tells them to heal themselves, and his follower Mary Magdalene attempts to calm him. Fearing that Jesus' movement is getting out of control, Judas goes to the Priests and tells them where Jesus will be the following night. The Priests pay him with 30 pieces of silver. Judas arrives at Jesus' location with Roman soldiers and identifies Jesus by kissing him on the cheek. The soldiers arrest Jesus and send him to Caiaphas, then Pontius Pilate, King Herod, and finally back to Pilate, who condemns him to death on the cross. ==Cast and characters== ===Main=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[John Legend]] as [[Jesus Christ]] * [[Sara Bareilles]] as [[Mary Magdalene]] * [[Brandon Victor Dixon]] as [[Judas Iscariot]] * [[Alice Cooper]] as [[Herod Antipas|King Herod]] * [[Norm Lewis]] as [[Caiaphas]] * [[Ben Daniels]] as [[Pontius Pilate]] * [[Jason Tam]] as [[Saint Peter|Peter]] * Jin Ha as [[Annas]] * [[Erik Grönwall]] as [[Simon the Zealot|Simon Zealotes]] {{div col end}} ===Ensemble=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * Melody Betts * Felicia Boswell * Abby Corrigan * Micaela Diamond * Rory Donovan * Christine Dwyer * Mike Evariste * F. Michael Haynie * Charissa Hogeland * Bre Jackson * Mykal Kilgore * Billy Lewis Jr. * Justin Gregory Lopez * Angel Lozada * Vince Oddo * Kyle Taylor Parker * [[Joel Perez]] * Jonah Platt * Conor Ryan * Christina Sajous * Justin Matthew Sargent * Heath Saunders * Joey Taranto * Syndee Winters * [[Lauren Zakrin]] {{div col end}} ===Dancers=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * Chloe Davis * Timothy Edwards * Shelby Finnie * Bahiyah Hibah * Juel D. Lane * Terk Lewis * Mayte Natalio * Sarah Parker * Willie Smith III * Maleek Washington {{div col end}} ==Musical numbers== The musical numbers from the track list of the soundtrack.{{cite web|title=Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert (Original Soundtrack of the NBC Television Event) by Original Television Cast of Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert on Apple Music|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert/1359176580|website=iTunes|accessdate=March 31, 2018|date=April 6, 2018}} {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Act I * "Overture" – Orchestra * "Heaven on Their Minds" – Judas * "What's the Buzz / Strange Thing Mystifying" – Judas, Jesus, Mary, and Ensemble * "[[Everything's Alright (Jesus Christ Superstar song)|Everything's Alright]]" – Mary, Judas, Jesus, and Ensemble * "[[This Jesus Must Die]]" – Caiaphas, Annas, and Ensemble * "Hosanna" – Jesus, Caiaphas, and Ensemble * "Simon Zealotes / Poor Jerusalem" - Simon Zealotes and Ensemble * "Pilate's Dream" – Pontius Pilate * "The Temple" - Jesus and Ensemble * "Everything's Alright (Reprise)" – Jesus and Mary * "[[I Don't Know How to Love Him]]" – Mary * "Damned for All Time / Blood Money" – Judas, Annas, Caiaphas, and Ensemble {{col-break}} ;Act II * "The Last Supper" – Jesus, Judas, and Ensemble * "Gethsemane (I Only Want to Say)" – Jesus * "Transition" – Jesus and Judas * "The Arrest" – Jesus, Peter, Annas, Caiaphas, and Ensemble * "Peter's Denial" – Peter, Mary, and Ensemble * "Pilate and Christ" – Pilate, Soldier, Jesus, Ensemble * "King Herod's Song" – Herod and Company * "Transition After Herod" – Orchestra * "Could We Start Again, Please?" – Mary and Peter * "Judas' Death" – Judas, Annas, Caiaphas, and Ensemble * "Trial Before Pilate (Including the 39 Lashes)" – Pilate, Caiaphas, Jesus, and Ensemble * "[[Superstar (Jesus Christ Superstar song)|Superstar]]" – Judas and Ensemble * "The Crucifixion" – Jesus and Ensemble * "John Nineteen: Forty One" – Orchestra {{col-end}} ==Production== ===Development=== On May 10, 2017, it was announced that [[NBC]] had selected ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]'' to be their next live musical event. Executive producers were expected to include [[Craig Zadan]], [[Neil Meron]], [[Marc Platt (producer)|Marc Platt]], [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]], and [[Tim Rice]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/jesus-christ-superstar-nbc-live-musical-1202422678/|title=‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Set as NBC’s Next Live Musical|first=Elizabeth|last=Wagmeister|date=May 10, 2017|website=Variety.com|accessdate=November 10, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Gans|first=Andrew|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/nbc-will-broadcast-jesus-christ-superstar-live|title=NBC Will Broadcast Jesus Christ Superstar Live! - Playbill|website=Playbill.com|date=May 10, 2017|accessdate=November 10, 2017}}{{citation|work=Entertainment Weekly|title=Jesus Christ Superstar is NBC's next live musical|author=James Hibberd |date=May 10, 2017|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/05/10/jesus-christ-superstar-nbc-musical/}} In December 2017, it was reported that British theater director [[David Leveaux]] would direct{{cite web|last1=Pedersen|first1=Erik|title=‘Jesus Christ Superstar Live!’: Alice Cooper to Play King Herod; David Leveaux Directs|url=http://deadline.com/2017/12/jesus-christ-superstar-live-alice-cooper-king-herod-david-leveaux-director-1202222910/|website=Deadline|accessdate=December 8, 2017|date=December 8, 2017}} and that the show would be performed in front of a live audience at the Marcy Avenue Armory in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]].{{cite web|last1=White|first1=Peter|title=John Legend To Play Jesus In NBC’s ‘Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert!’|url=http://deadline.com/2017/12/john-legend-to-star-as-jesus-in-nbcs-jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert-1202229660/|website=Deadline|accessdate=December 20, 2017|date=December 19, 2017}} Members of the creative crew included costume designer [[Paul Tazewell]] and choreographer [[Camille A. Brown]].{{cite web|last1=Littleton|first1=Cynthia|title=Music and Audience Take Center Stage in NBC’s ‘Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert’|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert-john-legend-nbc-easter-1202712779/|website=Variety|accessdate=March 30, 2018|date=February 28, 2018}} ===Casting=== In December 2017, it was announced that [[Alice Cooper]] had been cast as King Herod and [[John Legend]] had been cast in the title role of Jesus Christ. The following month, it was announced that [[Sara Bareilles]] would play Mary Magdalene.{{cite web|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=‘Jesus Christ Superstar’: Sara Bareilles To Play Mary Magdalene In NBC Live Staging|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/jesus-christ-superstar-sara-bareilles-cast-mary-magdalene-in-nbc-live-staging-1202237089/|website=Deadline|accessdate=January 6, 2018|date=January 6, 2018}} In February 2018, it was announced that [[Brandon Victor Dixon]], [[Norm Lewis]], [[Ben Daniels]], [[Jason Tam]], Jin Ha and [[Erik Grönwall]] had been cast as Judas, Caiaphas, Pontius Pilate, Peter, Annas and Simon Zealotes, respectively.{{cite web|last1=Clement|first1=Olivia|title=Hamilton's Brandon Victor Dixon to Star as Judas In NBC’s Live Jesus Christ Superstar {{!}} Playbill|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/hamiltons-brandon-victor-dixon-to-star-as-judas-in-nbcs-live-jesus-christ-superstar|website=Playbill|accessdate=February 24, 2018|language=en|date=February 22, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment/tv/tv-guy/os-et-jesus-christ-superstar-norm-lewis-plays-caiaphas-20180222-story.html|title='Jesus Christ Superstar': Norm Lewis to play Caiaphas|last=Boedeker|first=Hal|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=February 2, 2018|access-date=February 2, 2018|language=en-US}}{{cite web|last1=Ramos|first1=Dino-Ray|title=‘Hamilton’ Star Brandon 2018|date=February 22, 2018}} The production included a cast of forty-four actors, including [[Joel Perez]] and [[Lauren Zakrin]], and additional dancers.{{cite web|last1=Dawn|first1=Randee|title=NBC’s ‘Jesus Christ Superstar Live’ Blends the Crafts|url=https://variety.com/2018/artisans/news/jesus-christ-superstar-live-nbc-crafts-1202736626/|website=Variety|accessdate=April 1, 2018|date=March 28, 2018}}{{cite web|title=Flip Through Our Exclusive Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert Playbill {{!}} Playbill|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/flip-through-our-exclusive-jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert-playbill|website=Playbill|accessdate=April 1, 2018|language=en|date=March 30, 2018}}{{cite web|title=Credits {{!}} NBCUniversal Media Village|url=https://www.nbcumv.com/studios-distribution/universal-television/jesus-christ-superstar-live-concert/credits?network=33126|website=NBCUniversal Media Village|accessdate=April 1, 2018}} ===Filming=== The live production included an on-camera audience of about 1,500 people. Some of these extras lined two sides of the stage and formed a [[Moshing|mosh pit]] effect.{{cite web|last1=Zuckerman|first1=Esther|title=Can Jesus Christ Superstar Live Capture the Holy Grail?|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/03/jesus-christ-superstar-live-nbc-musical-john-legend-sara-bareilles|website=Variety|accessdate=April 1, 2018|language=en|date=March 29, 2018}} The production was expected to utilize as many as twelve cameras to film the special. In addition, a full dress rehearsal performance took place on Saturday, March 31, 2018 in front of an invited audience and was recorded. In the event of any difficulties during the live broadcast, the recording served as an emergency backup. It was ultimately not needed.{{cite web|last1=Brandt|first1=Robert|title=Drummer Jamey Tate Talks Jesus Christ Superstar Live|url=https://prologix.blog/2018/04/03/drummer-jamey-tate-talks-jesus-christ-superstar-live/|website=Prologix Percussion Blog|accessdate=April 7, 2018|language=en|date=April 3, 2018}} ===Marketing=== On January 7, 2018, NBC aired the first teaser trailer for the special during their broadcast of the [[75th Golden Globe Awards]].{{cite web|last1=Hayes|first1=Dade|title=NBC Promo For ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Primes Viewers For Easter Music Miracle|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/nbc-promo-for-jesus-christ-superstar-primes-viewers-for-easter-music-miracle-1202237933/|website=Deadline|accessdate=April 1, 2018|date=January 8, 2018}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== ''Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert'' has been met with an overwhelmingly positive response from critics since it aired. On the review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the production holds a 100% approval rating with an average rating of 8.5 out of 10 based on 23 reviews. The website's critical consensus reads, "Shaking up traditional religious and musical iconography, ''Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert'' is a sight to be heard, superbly infiltrating the classic source material with originality, rock legend star power, and soulful depth."{{cite web|title=Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert (2018)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/jesus_christ_superstar_live_in_concert/|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]]|accessdate=April 10, 2018|language=en}} [[Metacritic]], which uses a weighted average, assigned the production a score of 81 out of 100 based on 13 critics, indicating "universal acclaim".{{cite web|title=Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert Reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=April 2, 2018}} In a positive review, ''[[The New York Times]]''{{'}}s Noel Murray praised the special saying, "A conceptual and artistic triumph, NBC’s live telecast of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' on Easter Sunday may have finally justified the recent live musical fad on network TV. Some technical flubs and one mixed-bag lead performance aside, the production was genuinely thrilling, taking chances with the staging of a classic but controversial Broadway show, much more daring than previous live musical broadcasts like ''The Sound of Music'' or ''Peter Pan''."{{cite web|last1=Murray|first1=Noel|title=Review: In ‘Jesus Christ Superstar,’ an Old Story for (Yet Another) New Millennium|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/02/arts/television/jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert-nbc-review.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=April 3, 2018|date=April 2, 2018}} Offering similar acclaim, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''{{'}}s David Rooney said, "But here's the thing: This was a phenomenally balanced production of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'', in which star power was equaled by depth of feeling and characterization in all the principals. And the immediacy of television, with close-ups capable of bringing us in tight on the performers' faces, gave Jesus and Mary Magdalene a complexity that often is missing from conventional productions."{{cite web|last1=Rooney|first1=David|title='Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert': TV Review|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert-1098854|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=April 3, 2018|language=en|date=April 1, 2018}} Lorraine Ali of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' also lauded the production saying, "The show was a collision of religion and theater and pop culture that could have been one holy mess. But by the grace of God, or maybe a great cast and lots and lots of expert staging, a great musical became a great TV production."{{cite web|last1=Ali|first1=Lorraine|title=NBC's 'Jesus Christ Superstar Live' shouldn't have worked. Here's why it did|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-la-et-st-jesus-christ-superstar-review-20180402-story.html|website=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=April 3, 2018|date=April 2, 2018}} In a more mixed review, Maureen Ryan of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said, "This musical threw together glitter, sequins, leather, writhing hotties, a few big performances pitched to the last row, and camerawork that often felt as though it was hopped up on too many lattes. Actually, the ragged edges of a unifying concept did emerge over the course of the NBC musical’s two-hour-and-20-minute running time: If its philosophy could be summed up in one word, “excess” would just about cover it. That’s not necessarily a bad thing. But this live show was a lot."{{cite web|last1=Ryan|first1=Maureen|title=TV Review: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert’ on NBC|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/reviews/jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert-nbc-john-legend-brandon-victor-dixon-sara-bareilles-1202741222/|website=Variety|accessdate=April 3, 2018|date=April 1, 2018}} ===Ratings=== The production was watched by a total of 9.6 million viewers and earned a 1.7 rating in adults 18-49 in Live + Same Day.{{cite web|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=‘Jesus Christ Superstar Live In Concert’ Tops ‘American Idol’ & ‘The Passion’ To Lead Easter Sunday Ratings – Update|url=http://deadline.com/2018/04/jesus-christ-superstar-live-in-concert-ratings-american-idol-the-passion-1202356749/|website=Deadline|accessdate=April 2, 2018|date=April 2, 2018}} It was the most-viewed program of the night of both network and cable programming.{{cite web|url=http://www.showbuzzdaily.com/articles/showbuzzdailys-top-150-sunday-cable-originals-network-finals-4-1-2018.html|title=Updated: ShowBuzzDaily's Top 150 Sunday Cable Originals & Network Finals: 4.1.2018|work=Showbuzz Daily|author=Metcalf, Mitch|date=April 3, 2018|access-date=April 3, 2018}} ===Awards and nominations=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" |- ! scope="col"| Award ! scope="col"| Category ! The '''Martin Eisenstadt''' hoax is an elaborate scheme of filmmakers [[Dan Mirvish]] and [[Eitan Gorlin]] that involved the creation of a fictional [[Pundit (expert)|"talking head"]], Martin Eisenstadt, who was quoted by numerous major news outlets (such as the [[Los Angeles Times]] and [[MSNBC]]<ref>[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2008/nov/14/pranksters-get-the-last-laugh/ Pranksters get the last laugh N.Y. Times and MSNBC biggest victims ]</ref>), as well as countless blogs, all of which failed to verify his actual existence. "Eisenstadt" claimed to be the source of commentary about [[Sarah Palin]] in the wake of [[John McCain]]'s 2008 [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|presidential campaign]].<ref name="nonexist">{{cite news|title=A Senior Fellow at the Institute of Nonexistence|author=Pérez-Peña, Richard|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/13/arts/television/13hoax.html|date=2008-11-13|accessdate=2008-11-12}}</ref> Mirvish and Gorlin have since written a satirical novel called ''I Am Martin Eisenstadt: One Man's (Wildly Inappropriate) Adventures with the Last Republicans'' for [[Farrar, Straus and Giroux]] {{ISBN|978-0-86547-914-2}}. The book was written under Eisenstadt's pseudonym and purports to be a first-person memoir of Eisenstadt's experience with the McCain/Palin campaign, including buying Palin's wardrobe. In the book, the Eisenstadt character denies rumors that he does not exist.<ref>{{cite web|title=True Lies |author=Joshua Green |work=The Washington Monthly |url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2009/0911.green.html |accessdate=2009-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100201181235/http://washingtonmonthly.com/features/2009/0911.green.html |archivedate=2010-02-01 |df= }}</ref>
==Background== In 2007, Mirvish and Gorlin created short videos for [[YouTube]], with Gorlin playing a parking valet, Sheldon, who spewed effusive (and offensive) praise of then-presidential candidate [[Rudolph Giuliani]]. The original short film ''Sheldon'' played at the U.S. Comedy Arts Film Festival in Aspen in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=Waitress Opens US Comedy Arts Film Fest|work=The Hollywood Reporter|url=http://riskybusiness.blogs.thr.com/2007/02/waitress_opens_.html|accessdate=2009-12-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120719003946/http://riskybusiness.blogs.thr.com/2007/02/waitress_opens_.html|archivedate=2012-07-19|df=}} </ref> After Giuliani's campaign ceased, the character was modified to be a Sr. Fellow at the "Harding Institute for Freedom and Democracy", a fictional entity named in jest for one of the least-respected US presidents, [[Warren G. Harding]]. The pair created a website for the Harding Institute, created the character of the commentator, dubbed Martin Eisenstadt, played again by Gorlin.
Dan Mirvish is a former speechwriter for Democratic Senator [[Tom Harkin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=On a Roll at Wendy's Window|author= Argetsinger, Amy and Roxanne Roberts|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/01/26/AR2006012602499.html|date=2006-01-27|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=2008-11-14}}</ref> He is also a feature film director and co-founder of the [[Slamdance Film Festival]]. Gorlin was nominated for the Someone to Watch Award at the 2003 IFP [[Independent Spirit Award]]s for his film ''The Holy Land''.<ref>{{cite web|title=2003 IFP Independent Spirit Awards - Nominees and Winners|work=About.com |url=http://movies.about.com/library/weekly/aaifpnom2002.htm |accessdate=2009-12-15}}</ref>
==Hoaxes== The first appearance of Martin Eisenstadt was in a video of a phony interview, purportedly on [[Al Iraqiya]], describing his plan to build [[casino]]s in the [[Green Zone]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Iraq Green Zone getting Casinos in Baghdad |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L27uHysoQP0|accessdate=2008-11-22}}</ref> The report was accepted at face value and blogged by [[Jonathan Stein]] of [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Stein |first=Jonathan |title=McCain Adviser Says...Wow, Just Watch for Yourself |url=https://www.motherjones.com/mojoblog/archives/2008/07/8918_mccain_adviser_1.html |format=blog |date=2008-07-07 }}</ref> but correctly and tentatively identified as [[satire]] by the [[Monthly Review]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Iraq: We All Work for the Casino in the Green Zone |journal=Monthly Review |year=2008 |issue=27/06/08 |url=http://www.monthlyreview.org/mrzine/eisenstadt270608.html |accessdate=2008-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106005338/http://www.monthlyreview.org/mrzine/eisenstadt270608.html |archivedate=January 6, 2009 }}</ref> By this point, Brazilian-based golf blogger William Wolfram had already extensively researched Eisenstadt and concluded he did not exist.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Martin Eisenstadt Chronicles |url=http://www.williamkwolfrum.com/the-martin-eisenstadt-chronicles/|accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nationwide hoax exposed from a laptop in Apple Valley|url=http://www.vvdailypress.com/news/valley-10328-apple-exposed.html|accessdate=2009-12-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927162836/http://www.vvdailypress.com/news/valley-10328-apple-exposed.html|archivedate=2011-09-27|df=}}</ref>
During and after the election campaign, several hoaxes perpetrated by Eisenstadt (Gorlin and Mirvish) were reported by news organizations and blogs as truthful, including reports that [[Joe the Plumber]] was a cousin of [[Charles Keating]] and that [[Paris Hilton]]'s family strongly protested the McCain campaign's comparison of [[Barack Obama]] to Hilton.<ref name="nonexist"/>
After election day, 2008, it was widely reported that a senior McCain advisor had stated that Palin was unaware that [[Africa]] was a continent rather than a country.<ref>{{cite news|title=Palin Calls Criticism by McCain Aides 'Cruel and Mean-Spirited'|author=Yardley, William and Michael Cooper|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/08/us/politics/08palin.html |accessdate=2008-11-07 | date=2008-11-08}}</ref> After the story broke, Mirvish and Gorlin released a video where Eisenstadt, reportedly a McCain policy adviser, made that statement. Mirvish and Gorlin said that they did not invent the story but only took the credit for it after it broke as being the source. Several mainstream news outlets publicised this attribution.
The AP, noting that "Eisenstadt's 'work' had been quoted and debunked before," reported that the hoax "was limited to the identity of the source in the story about Palin - not the Fox News story itself."<ref>11-12-2008. Bauder, David. [http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/P/PALIN_HOAX?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT MSNBC retracts false Palin story; others duped]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''[[The Associated Press]]''</ref> Mirvish himself, in a [[BBC]] interview, admits that they falsely took credit as being the source, but stated that the story itself could be true.<ref>{{cite news |title=How Sarah Palin was Hoaxed |format=BBC audio |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_7726000/7726706.stm |accessdate=2008-11-13 | date=2008-11-13 | work=BBC News}}</ref>
According to Mirvish it would have taken "about 20 seconds of searching to realize Eisenstadt was a hoax."<ref>ABC News [http://www.abcnews.go.com/Politics/Vote2008/Story?id=6250151&page=2 Martin Eisenstadt: Pundit or Fraud?]</ref> "With the [[24-hour news cycle]] they rush into anything they can find" added Mirvish.<ref name="NYT">[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/13/arts/television/13hoax.html?bl&ex=1226811600&en=69c9c3988c55907d&ei=5087%0A A Senior Fellow at the Institute of Nonexistence ]</ref> The hoax revealed lack of fact-checking by news outlets such as MSNBC. An MSNBC spokesman stated that someone in the newsroom received the item in an e-mail, and that no vetting was ever done on it.<ref name="NYT" />
In May 2009, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' reported that Eisenstadt was one of the "elite Twitterati" who attended the [[White House Correspondents Dinner]], along with [[Meghan McCain]], [[Ashton Kutcher]], and [[Newt Gingrich]].<ref>{{cite news|title=You Won't Believe What Martin Eisenstadt Said At The White House Correspondents Dinner |author=Diane Tucker|work=The Huffington Post |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/diane-tucker/you-wont-believe-what-mar_b_201923.html |accessdate=2009-12-15 |date=2009-10-10}}</ref> Time later retracted its original reporting.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tweets From a Washington Dinner (a.k.a. #nerdprom) |author=Hchuaeoan and Ssss1222|work=Time |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1897138-3,00.html | date=2009-05-09 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref>
==Book== Mirvish and Gorlin wrote the book ''I Am Martin Eisenstadt: One Man's (wildly inappropriate) Adventures with the Last Republicans'' which was published in November, 2009, by [[Farrar, Straus and Giroux]]. The authors went on a book tour that included a Washington, DC, party thrown for them by former President [[Bill Clinton]] press secretary [[Joe Lockhart]] and other Washington notables including [[Karen Finney]], [[Matthew Cooper (American journalist)]] and [[Michael Feldman (consultant)|Michael Feldman]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Will the Real 'Martin Eisenstadt' Please Stand Up |author=Roxanne Roberts and Amy Argetsinger|work=The Washington Post |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/reliable-source/2009/11/will_the_real_martin_eisenstad.html |accessdate=2009-12-15}}</ref>
==Videos== Mirvish and Gorlin's first collaboration was a promo for a video game for Mirvish's film Open House. The character they created turned into Sheldon, the bitter valet, for the eponymously titled short film that screened at the 2007 U.S. Comedy Arts Festival in Aspen. The duo shot seven more similar shorts and posted them anonymously on YouTube as faux Rudolph Giuliani ads during early primary season for the 2008 U.S. Presidential campaign.<ref name="Dana Harris">{{cite news|title=Behind the Sarah Palin hoax: Interview with Dan Mirvish |author=Dana Harris |work=Variety |url=http://weblogs.variety.com/hal/2008/11/behind-the-sara.html |accessdate=2009-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100826065917/http://weblogs.variety.com/hal/2008/11/behind-the-sara.html |archivedate=August 26, 2010 }}</ref> The Giuliani campaign denied any involvement with the ads.<ref>{{cite news|title=It's Tricky |author=Dan Saltzstein|work=The New York Times |url=http://themedium.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/07/30/its-tricky/ |accessdate=2009-12-30 | date=2007-07-30}}</ref> The ads created their own controversy when the consulting company who had produced the Swift Boat ads of 2004 was erroneously blamed for them under the assumption they were some sort of dirty tricks campaign by one of Giuliani's rivals.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dirty Tricks Dot-Com? Mystery Online Vids Slam GOP Hopefuls |author=Brian Ross|work=ABC News |url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/theblotter/2007/07/dirty-tricks-do.html |accessdate=2009-12-30}}</ref>
The filmmakers had planned to develop The Bitter Valet into a TV series, but due to the 2008 Writers Guild Strike, they shelved that plan and came up with the Martin Eisenstadt character. The first thing they filmed with Eisenstadt was the alleged interview on Iraqi TV, which was actually filmed in Mirvish's garage in California.<ref name="Dana Harris"/>
During the fall of 2008, Gorlin and Mirvish filmed a fake 40-minute BBC documentary entitled "The Last Republican," which they then posted on YouTube in 10 parts. They also filmed four rebuttals allegedly from Martin Eisenstadt in Washington, DC, in which Eisenstadt threatened to sue the documentarian and the BBC for taking him out of context. In fact, the filmmakers later admitted that "The Last Republican" was actually a pilot for a television show they were developing.<ref name="Dana Harris"/>
==Harding Prize for Best Crafted Apologies== In April, 2010, Mirvish and Gorlin created an award called "The Harding Prize for Best Crafted Apology" named after President [[Warren G. Harding]], who once apologized for his presidency by saying "I am not fit for this office and should never have been here."<ref>{{cite web |title=Satirical pundit, Martin Eisenstadt, awards 'Harding' prize for apologies |author=Howie Perlman|work=The Eagle|url=http://www.theeagleonline.com/news/story/satirical-pundit-martin-eisenstadt-awards-harding-prize-for-apologies/|accessdate=2010-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= The Perfect 'Sorry': an Art and Science: The first annual Best Crafted Apology awards|author=Teneille Gibson|work=NBCWashington.com|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/weird/The-Perfect-Sorry-An-Art-and-Science-90746749.html|accessdate=2010-04-14}}</ref> Awarded in a ceremony at [[American University]], Gorlin (as Martin Eisenstadt) presented the Harding Prizes in several categories: [[Rahm Emanuel]] won for Politics, [[Tiger Woods]] for Sports, [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] for Entertainment, and [[Adam Carolla]] won in the best Twitter apology category.<ref>{{cite web |title=Emanuel awarded for Best Political Apology; Arenas nominated|author=Nikki Schwab & Tara Palmeri|work=The Washington Examiner|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/politics/blogs/yeas-and-nays/Spoofed_-Emanuel-awarded-for-Best-Political-Apology_-Arenas-nominated-90703589.html|accessdate=2010-04-14}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

(until 1 March 2015){{Cite news|title=U.S.-backed Syria rebel group dissolves itself after losses|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-rebels/u-s-backed-syria-rebel-group-dissolves-itself-after-losses-idUSKBN0LX1L720150301|date=1 March 2015|accessdate=1 March 2015|publisher=Reuters Media}} |units2 = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Syrian Arab Army.svg}} [[Syrian Army]]: *[[Suqur al-Sahara]] |strength1 = |strength2 = |casualties1 = 540+ killed |casualties2 = 270+ killed |casualties3 = |campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Battle of Aleppo}} }} '''Operation Rainbow''' was an operation launched by the [[Syrian Army]], supported by [[Hezbollah]] and other allied militias, during the [[Syrian Civil War]], following [[Operation Canopus Star|a successful operation]] which led to the military encircling [[Aleppo]] from the east side and reaching the city's northern approach. The aim of the operation, as the previous one, was to encircle Aleppo and cut rebel supply lines into the city, thus besieging rebel-held areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2014/1209/Can-UN-envoy-sell-cease-fire-to-Syria-rebels-Not-so-fast.-video|title=Can UN envoy sell cease-fire to Syria rebels? Not so fast. (+video)|author=Dominique Soguel|date=9 December 2014|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=9 December 2014}} == The operation == ===Battle for the north-eastern approach=== On 7 December, the Army captured the Breij area, on the northeastern outskirts of the city,{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/12/syria-nusra-front-makes-gains-deraa-2014127183023470829.html|title=Reports: Syrian rebels make gains in Deraa|author=Al Jazeera And AFP|publisher=|accessdate=15 December 2014}} and advanced towards the al-Owayji area to the west and the al-Enzarat area to the south.[http://syriahr.com/en/2014/12/24-fighters-of-the-islamic-battalions-and-20-members-of-the-regime-forces-killed-in-aleppo-today/ 24 fighters of the Islamic battalions and 20 members of the regime forces killed in Aleppo today]{{dead link|date=June 2015}} The next day, the Army moved around Handarat and captured the al-Hajal and al-Majbal districts overlooking Hanano, Haydariya and Duwayr al-Jandul.{{cite web|title=Syria army advance around Handarat|url=https://twitter.com/EjmAlrai/status/541944524541812736|website=Elijah J. Magnier|accessdate=8 December 2014}} After this, government forces entered the Baya’adeen district, taking up positions in its southern part.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-syrian-army-enters-another-rebel-held-district/|title=Aleppo: Syrian Army Enters Another Rebel-Held District|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=15 December 2014}} On 11 December, government forces recaptured territory in the Stone Quarries in the southern part of Breij they lost the previous week. The military further advanced past the Stone Quarries and pushed south towards the Hanano district. The fighting over the previous seven days left more than 60 rebels dead, according to a military source.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-60-islamic-front-militants-killed-al-bureijj/|title=Aleppo: Over 60 Islamic Front Militants Killed at Al-Bureijj|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=15 December 2014}} The next day, the Army captured the Wood Factory near the Jandoul roundabout, and established positions near the Saraya Night Club.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-syrian-army-advances-strategic-al-jandoul-roundabout/|title=Aleppo: The Syrian Army Advances to the Strategic Al-Jandoul Roundabout|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=15 December 2014}} By the end of the day, the military reportedly had fire control over both the Ba'edin and Jandoul roundabouts on the Castello Road.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/PetoLucem/status/543712482721021952|title=Peto Lucem on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=15 December 2014}} On 14 December, the Army advanced into{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/12/10-fighters-at-least-killed-in-aleppo-clashes-and-the-regime-forces-advance-towards-al-mallah-area/|title=10 fighters at least killed in Handarat clashes, and the regime forces advance towards al- Mallah area.|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=15 December 2014}} and captured the al-Mallah area, with further attempts by the military to capture the area west of al-Mallah and thus finally cut the Castello Road.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/12/regime-forces-advances-in-aleppo-and-kills-no-less-than-21-fighters/|title=Regime forces advances in Aleppo and kills no less than 21 fighters|author=Master|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=15 December 2014}} Two hours later, according to a pro-government source, the Army captured the neighboring Mara’ashli Farms.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/updated-battle-map-aleppo-syrian-army-captures-al-malaah/#prettyPhoto|title=Updated Battle Map of Aleppo: Syrian Army Captures Al-Malaah|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=15 December 2014}} Government forces also advanced and captured the southern and western parts of the Handarat city district,{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/EjmAlrai/status/544071306711691264|title=Elijah J. Magnier on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=15 December 2014}} closing in on Handarat hill which overlooks the Castello Road. 34 rebels and nine soldiers were killed during the day.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30471070|title=BBC News - Syria conflict: Assad forces move on Aleppo supply hill|work=BBC News|accessdate=15 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/12/34-fighters-killed-by-clashes-against-regime-forces-north-of-aleppo/|title=34 fighters killed by clashes against regime forces north of Aleppo|author=Master|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=15 December 2014}} The advances brought government forces within a few hundred meters of surrounding Aleppo.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/middleeast/article4298327.ece|title=Assad strangles Aleppo as fresh refugee crisis looms|work=The Times|accessdate=26 January 2015}} More fighting the next day left 14 rebels dead,{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/2014/12/%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D9%88%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D8%B9-14-%D9%85%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%8B-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%82/|title=استشهاد ومصرع 14 مقاتلاً من الفصائل المقاتلة والإسلامية وجبهة النصرة في منطقة الملاح شمال حلب|author=Anas|work=المرصد السورى لحقوق الإنسان|accessdate=26 January 2015}} as the Army captured a hill overlooking the rebel supply line.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/joshua_landis/status/544504124285284353|title=Joshua Landis on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=26 January 2015}} On 17 December, 16 soldiers were killed in fighting in the al-Mallah area where the rebels captured eight buildings, while the Army recaptured Aghob hill and the al-Fawaz area of Breij.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/12/16-soldiers-in-regime-forces-killed-during-clashes-in-al-mallah-farmlands/|title=16 soldiers in regime forces killed during clashes in al-Mallah farmlands|author=Master|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=26 January 2015}} Al-Arabiya reported government forces were close to capturing Handarat hill and completing the siege,{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/views/news/middle-east/2014/12/17/Will-Aleppo-freeze-or-fall-.html|title=Will Aleppo freeze or fall?|publisher=|accessdate=16 February 2015}} while the pro-government [[Al-Masdar News]] agency reported the troops had already captured all of the remaining hills along the Castello Road and were focusing on the main roundabout.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-final-rebel-supply-route-verge-obstruction/|title=Aleppo: Final Rebel Supply Route on the Verge of Obstruction|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=26 January 2015}} At the end of the day, the military made another advance in the Handarat area{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/626221757486166|title=Aleppo Province: The helicopters dropped... - Syrian Observatory for Human Rights - Facebook|publisher=|accessdate=26 January 2015}} and by 19 December had captured all{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/edwardedark/status/545638757672960000|title=Edward Dark on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=26 January 2015}} or a part of the Handarat district.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/12/the-regime-forces-advance-in-handarat-area/|title=The regime forces advance in Handarat area|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=26 January 2015}} On 22 December, the rebels recaptured the industrial plants in the northern part of the Handarat district, however they lost it again one week later after an assault by Army and Hezbollah troops.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-syrian-army-retakes-industrial-plants-handarat/|title=Aleppo: The Syrian Army Retakes the Industrial Plants in Handarat|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=26 January 2015}} By 1 January 2015, the military had captured 16 plants in the Al-Shahel area of the Handarat district.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-syrian-army-takes-control-16-industrial-plants-handarat/|title=Aleppo: The Syrian Army Takes Control of 16 Industrial Plants in Handarat|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=26 January 2015}} ===Rebel counter-attack=== On 5 January, the rebels recaptured the Majbal (Sawmills) area of al-Brej after fighting that killed or wounded no less than 20 soldiers. They also captured the southern entrance of the stone quarries known as al-Misat, forcing government troops to retreat to the north.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/01/20-soldiers-in-regime-forces-killed-during-clashes-in-al-brej-area/|title=20 soldiers in regime forces killed during clashes in al-Brej area|author=Master|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=26 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-battle-al-bureijj-intensifies/|title=Aleppo: The Battle for Al-Bureijj Intensifies|author=Leith Fadel|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|accessdate=26 January 2015}} {{anchor|Aleppo Central Prison}}Later, it was reported the rebels managed to seize the al-Manasher al-Breij area and were trying to advance and take control over al-Brej Hill with which they could seize the military supply road from the Aleppo Central Prison to the Handarat and al-Mallah areas.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/01/al-jabha-al-islameyyi-and-jaysho-al-muhajereen-wal-al-anasar-seize-manasher-al-brej-area/|title=Al- Jabha al- Islameyyi and Jaysho al- Muhajereen wal al- Anasar seize Manasher al- Brej area|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=26 January 2015}} The next day, the rebels reportedly took control over the al-Akhdar Mosque, a mill and the al-Tawattor al-Aali area of al-Brej.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/01/the-islamic-battalions-advance-and-seize-areas-in-al-brej-and-misat-areas/|title=The Islamic battalions advance and seize new positions in al- Brej and Misat areas|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=26 January 2015}} On 8 January, the Army and pro-government militias conducted a counter-attack against areas seized by the rebels in previous days.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-syrian-army-counters-rebel-offensive-northeast/|title=Aleppo: Syrian Army Counters the Rebel Offensive in the Northeast|author=Leith {{About|the theatre in Manchester, England|the theatre in Manchester, New Hampshire, United States|Palace Theatre (Manchester, New Hampshire)}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = Palace Theatre |image = The Palace Theatre, Oxford Road - geograph.org.uk - 1223578.jpg |image_size = 220px |caption = |address = [[Wilmslow Road|Oxford Street]] |city = [[Manchester]] |country = England |designation = [[Listed building|Grade II]] |latitude = |longitude = |architect = [[Alfred Darbyshire]] |owner = [[Ambassador Theatre Group]] |capacity = 1,955 (seated) |type = [[Theatre]] |opened = 18 May 1891 |renovated = 1913 (interior) by [[Bertie Crewe]] |yearsactive = 1891–present |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = |website = [http://www.atgtickets.com/venues/palace-theatre-manchester/ Palace Theatre Manchester website at Ambassador Theatre Group] }} The '''Palace Theatre, Manchester''', is one of the main theatres in [[Manchester]], England. It is situated on [[Wilmslow Road|Oxford Street]], on the north-east corner of the intersection with [[Whitworth Street]]. The Palace and its sister theatre the [[Manchester Opera House|Opera House]] on [[Quay Street]] are operated by the same parent company, [[Ambassador Theatre Group]]. The original capacity of 3,675 has been reduced to its current 1,955.<ref>{{cite web | title = Palace Theatre Manchester: Venue Hire |url = http://www.atgtickets.com/venues/palace-theatre-manchester/venue-hire/ | website = atgtickets.com | publisher = [[Ambassador Theatre Group]] | access-date = 24 November 2012 }}</ref>
==History== The theatre, originally known as the Grand Old Lady of Oxford Street, opened on 18 May 1891, having been designed by the architect [[Alfred Darbyshire]] at a cost of £40,500. The interior of the theatre was renovated under by [[Bertie Crewe]] in 1913, the renovation took seven months and the theatre reopened with a reduced seating capacity of 2,600.<ref>{{cite web | title = Palace Theatre Manchester: Overview |url = http://www.atgtickets.com/venues/palace-theatre-manchester/history/ | website = atgtickets.com | publisher = [[Ambassador Theatre Group]] | access-date = 3 August 2016 }}</ref>
In September 1940 the theatre took a direct hit from a German bomb during the [[Manchester Blitz]].{{r|IWM}}
In the 1970s audience numbers declined, as they did in many live venues, and it was threatened with closure. The [[Arts Council of Great Britain|Arts Council]] supported it in the 1980s, and after major internal refurbishment and an enlarged stage facility, it was run by a charitable trust, Norwest Holdings.
It is now one of the best equipped and popular theatres outside London. In its repertoire it hosts major touring musicals often with major celebrities and performances of opera and ballet along with various other comedy acts and one night concerts.
===Royal Opera House, Manchester=== {{main article|The Royal Ballet#Royal Opera House.2C Manchester}}
In 2008 the Royal Opera House and [[Manchester City Council]] began planning stages a new development known as '''Royal Opera House, Manchester'''. The proposal would have seen the Palace Theatre refurbished, to create a theatre capable of staging productions by both the [[The Royal Ballet|Royal Ballet]] and [[Royal Opera House|Royal Opera]]. It was intended that the Royal Opera House would take residence of the theatre for an annual 18-week season, staging 16 performances by the Royal Opera, 28 performances by the Royal Ballet and other small-scale productions.<ref>{{cite news | last = Higgins | first = Charlotte | title = Disharmony over Royal Opera's plan to go north | url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/oct/28/royal-opera-lowry-manchester | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 28 October 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Northern opera proposal evaluated | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7702690.stm | work = [[BBC News]] | publisher = [[BBC]] | date = 31 October 2008 }}</ref> A year later [[The Lowry]] sent an open letter to the then [[Secretary of State for Culture, Olympics, Media and Sport]], [[Ben Bradshaw]], Arts Council England, Manchester City Council and the ROH, calling for the scheme, in its current form, to be scrapped.<ref>{{cite news | last = Brown | first = Mark | title = Threat to plan for Royal Opera House in the north | url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jun/25/lowry-manchester-royal-opera-house | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 25 June 2009 }}</ref> In 2010 it was announced that the project was being shelved as part of larger arts-funding cuts.<ref name="Stage_031110">{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = ROH shelves its plans to move north | url = https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2010/roh-shelves-its-plans-to-move-north/ | work = [[The Stage]] | publisher = The Stage Media Company Ltd | date = 3 November 2010 }} [http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/news/show/2252-roh-shelves-its-plans-to-move-north Alternative link.]</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Sharp | first = Rob | title = Royal Opera House shelves move north | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/classical/news/royal-opera-house-shelves-move-north-2118505.html | work = [[The Independent]] | publisher = Independent Print Ltd | date = 27 October 2010 }}</ref>
== Productions == The opening presentation, to a capacity audience, was the [[ballet]] ''Cleopatra''; however its initial presentations failed to gain popular support and for several years it struggled to make a profit. Only when it broadened its scope to include more popular performers was it a resounding success. During the early part of the 20th century it came into its own, with artists such as [[Danny Kaye]], [[Gracie Fields]], [[Charles Laughton]], [[Judy Garland]], [[Noël Coward]] and [[Laurel and Hardy]] making appearances.
Continuing a long tradition of tour openings in Manchester, the hit [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and [[West End theatre|West End]] musical ''[[The Producers (musical)|The Producers]]'' opened at the theatre in February 2007 for a run until May when it continued on tour around the UK. [[Peter Kay]] starred as Roger Debris for the Manchester dates.
Other notable shows to have played successful seasons at the Palace Theatre include, amongst others, the regional premiere of ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' which ran for 13 months from 1992–93, regional premiere of ''[[Miss Saigon]]'' in 2001, ''[[Chitty Chitty Bang Bang (musical)|Chitty Chitty Bang Bang]]'' in 2006 and ''[[Mamma Mia!]]'' over the 2006/07 Christmas season. Broadway musical ''[[The Wedding Singer]]'' had its UK premiere at the theatre in 2008 and in December 2008 to March 2009 the theatre hosted a season of the UK tour of ''[[Mary Poppins]]'', one of only six theatres in the country to accommodate the tour, both events further cementing the theatre's reputation as the flagship venue of the [[Northern England|North of England]]. In July 2009, during the [[Manchester International Festival]], the theatre, in association with [[Opera North]], staged the world première of [[Rufus Wainwright]]'s [[opera]] ''[[Prima Donna (opera)|Prima Donna]]''.
